bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 161, Number 46 (Wednesday, March 18, 2015)]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. STIVERS:H.R. 1455.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:This bill is enacted pursuant to the power granted toCongress under Article I, section 8, Clause 3 of the UnitedStates Constitution. The Constitution's Commerce Clauseallows Congress to enact laws when reasonably related to theregulation of interstate commerce.[Page H1771]

item.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Health.
Referred to the House Committee on Energy and Commerce.

item.name: Department of Health and Human Services
Drug safety, medical device, and laboratory regulation

summary.text:
Speeding Access to Already Approved Pharmaceuticals Act of 2015

This bill amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to require the Food and Drug Administration to facilitate the development and expedite the review of a new drug, biological product, or device that has been approved in the European Union.

bill.title: Speeding Access to Already Approved Pharmaceuticals Act of 2015

item.title: Speeding Access to Already Approved Pharmaceuticals Act of 2015
To require the Food and Drug Administration to expedite review of pharmaceuticals that are approved for marketing in the European Union.
Speeding Access to Already Approved Pharmaceuticals Act of 2015

latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Health.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
